Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Ebon Feed Heat-Set**

Beware the Ebon's broiling day, my son,
When slithersnipe ignites the tarish gleam;
The vortexmaw will spunburn everyone—
Keep synthocool upon your pulsebeam.

Take up the cryo-caliber of trust,
My boy, the thermal neverwhens ring true;
Hear sizzle-hiss of plasm in the dust—
Now feed the heat-set, ebonite, and through.

Through thermavale and radiance he crept,
Where crackleflask kissed night to blistermorn;
The ebonite unlid, its hunger kept—
His cockleheart with cinderwarning torn.

"Ssslamtide!" it burbled, "Gloamgrill, feed!" it cried,
Its glowgullet a furnacebloom of dread;
He slashed the feedgate, coolant vortex-wide—
One hissflash—snuffed—its pyrelust fell dead.

Return, my beam-bright hero, furnace-tried!
Return with frost upon your vented brow;
For ebon feeds no more, its embers died—
Now chill the hearth, and seal the weldthreads now.

Beware the Ebon's broiling day, my son,
Though slithersnipe may spark the tarish gleam;  
The vortexmaw lies silent—heat-set done—  
We synthocool the pulse of every dream.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Grindlebore of Hollowglen

1  
Beware the hollow grind, my son,  
The bevel-bite, the wire-edge dun!  
Beware the strop-loop’s zither-hum,  
And shun the slurpy slinder-slum!  

2  
He took his hone of coticule,  
And oil-whetstone, cool and cruel;  
He honed the O1, thin and keen,  
Till sparks went skrithle-gold between.  

3  
Upon the bench, by candle-bleak,  
He honed the hollow, thin and meek;  
The burr did tibble-twitch and glide—  
A moon-bright whisker on the side.  

4  
Out from the scabbard, whiffle-quick,  
The blade gave one arthurtic click;  
It sang a skrill of metal glee—  
The Grindlebore was near the tree.  

5  
It came with whettle-whorling roar,  
Through knurly dusk it snarked and bore;  
Its teeth were notches, gapped and wide,  
Its breath a rasp of steel-etch tide.  

6  
One snicker-snack of arc-thin ray—  
The hollow bit the beast midway;  
The burr uncurled like silver floss,  
The Grindlebore became the dross.  

7  
He left it curled in shavings pale,  
A scroll of moonlight, thin and frail;  
He wiped the oil, he sheathed the blade—  
Back to the bench the sparks all swayed.  

8  
Come close, my child, and heed the line:  
The hollow grind is thin, divine;  
Yet thinness hums a snicker-snack—  
Beware the burr that answers back!

info.topic: hollow grind on an O1 blade

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Scriveleaf’s Warning  

  Beware the scroll-born, inked and scrolled,  
  Where quills in moonlit murkings scrawl;  
  The forged leaf glimmers, green and gold,  
  And whispers doom to one and all.  

  Take up the shardpen, splinted tight,  
  And dip it thrice in midnight dye;  
  Trace runes of reft-light, rifted night,  
  Lest scritchclaw catch you creeping by.  

  Now sling the satchel, strap it fast,  
  With whistle-wort and parchment dust;  
  Step soft where shadow-saplings cast  
  Their sigils in the sooty gust.  

  So stalled I, stooped in starless glen,  
  When rust-rattle rose from root to roof;  
  Leaves laughed like shattered violin—  
  Outflung, the forged leaf sprang aloof.  

  Its stem was hinge, its blade was brand,  
  Its veins a vorpal writhe of wire;  
  It smelt of sealing-wax and sand,  
  And hummed a hymnal forged in fire.  

  One slash—my satchel spilled its store;  
  Two slashes—runes rang rank and raw;  
  I roared a word no lip before  
  Had dared to dabble, draw, or gnaw.  

  “By blottish brink and blistery blot,  
  By smear and smudge I superscribe!”  
  I stabbed the scroll-spot, searing hot,  
  And ripped the leaf alike a scribe.  

  It shrieked—a scrinch, a scrannel squeal—  
  Then furled to flakes of chlorite;  
  The wind whisked every emerald peel  
  To distant dusk and dappled night.  

  Back home I hobble, scroll in hand,  
  Its edges still emboss-burnt black;  
  I lock it deep in iron stand—  
  Yet nightly hears the hinge-crack.  

  Beware the scroll-born, inked and scrolled,  
  Where quills in moonlit murkings scrawl;  
  The forged leaf glimmers, green and gold—  
  And whispers, “I unwrite you all.”

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiln witness cone bend". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Kilnwock's Watch

Beware the kiln-blink hour, my pet,  
When slibber cones begin to sweat;  
The glozen glazen silhouette  
Of witness-bends will snare you yet.  

Take up the tongs of tempered steel,  
The tundish-torch, the porcelesque wheel;  
Then tread the kilnpath, hush, heel by heel—  
The heat will hanker, hiss, and heal.  

O kilnwock, kilnwoe, kilnwhirl within!  
Its maw a magma-mirrored grin;  
It cracks the craquelure of skin—  
A fired and furtive mandolin.  

With whiffling draft I warped the door;  
The pyrometric prophets swore;  
I nudged the cone—no more, no more—  
It kinked, it knuckled, kissed the floor.  

“And hast thou bent the witness cone?  
O kiln-spawn child, well-fired, full-grown!  
Come homeward, clay-caked, gently blown—  
The kiln-blink hour is past, is flown.”  

Beware the kiln-blink hour, my pet,  
When slibber cones begin to sweat;  
The glozen glazen silhouette  
Of witness-bends will snare you yet.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "lead type in a composing stick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Quixtrel’s Quoin  
(Being a caution to compositors concerning the Quixtrel that lurks in a leaded stick)

1  
Beware the quixtrel’s squiddy squink,  
That wriggles twixt the kernèd lines;  
It slurps the serifs off your slugs  
And drools in dribbling glyphed designs.  

2  
Take up the planer, slick with ink,  
And bray the braying brayer’s bane;  
With measure set and margins pinked,  
Beat down the bruising bramble-stane.  

3  
For when the stick is tilted just—  
A clink!—the quixtrel quicks awake;  
It squirms through spacers, slick as rust,  
And leaves your layout half-baked.  

4  
It slithers up the composing rule,  
It nibbles nick and shoulder both;  
It gulps the gullets of your g’s  
And gargles glyphs in frothy froth.  

5  
Yet hush!—a hush of hushy hush—  
The pressman preps his pewter prod;  
He slides a skinny slug of brass  
To spike the squirming squishy sod.  

6  
He twizzles tight the tympan clamps,  
He thumps the platen once—then twice;  
The quixtrel quivers, quills retract,  
Its squiddy squink caught cold as ice.  

7  
A clomp!—a clump!—a clammy clap!—  
The lead lies level, locked and flat;  
The creature’s carcass, coined in quads,  
Is stapled to the forme like that.  

8  
Come, comb the compositor’s creed:  
Let quoin and key keep quixtrels corked;  
For if you nod, they’ll nib your need  
And nudge your pages into murk.  

9  
So pocket up your planer proud,  
And pocket every punch and peg;  
Else quixtrels quick will quilt your crowd  
In quilted quirks of queasy leg.  

10  
Beware the quixtrel’s squiddy squink—  
It slurps the serifs off your slugs;  
It wriggles twixt the kernèd lines…  
And drools in dribbling glyphed designs.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Urushimire's Cure**

Beware the urushi-bloom, my child,
Its drip-drop dappled gleam!
For vapours vile and varnish wild
Will bind you in its dream.

The glisten-gloss of lacquer-leaves
In moon-murk midnight dries;
Where urushimire softly grieves
With amber-oozing eyes.

Take up the tincture-tempered blade,
The cure-cloth cool and clasped;
Through fume-forests lightly wade—
Yet not too long unmasked.

The urushimire stirs in shade,
Its resin-ribs uncoil;
With slick-slurred step it snakes and strayed,
Its sap-skin starts to boil.

"And hast thou slain the urushimire?
Come cure thy crusted skin!
O frabjous day, callooh! Callay!"
He chortled, clear of sin.

Beware the urushi-bloom, my child,
Its drip-drop dappled gleam—
For vapours vile and varnish wild
Still bind you in its dream.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plum brown blueing bath". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Plum-Brown Blueing Bath**

In slurvy morn when wobblets cry,  
The plum-brown bath begins to sigh;  
Its blueing waves go “slorrp” and “splee”—  
Beware the splash, O Trindle-Tee!

She primps her plumes with peppermint,  
A brindle brush, a pepper-scent;  
She hums a hushful hexagram,  
And stuffs her socks with sug’ed ham.

With clinkled step and thripple heart,  
She twirls toward the tub’s dark start;  
Its steam goes “whorl” and “grindle-grath”—  
O Trindle, mind the blueing bath!

A glubber lurks beneath the suds,  
With nine noogle-nips and thuds;  
Its eyes like pickled prunes agleam—  
It’s called the *Slorthering Spleebly-Spleem*!

It “plorps,” it “gloops,” it “blorbles” loud,  
Its tongue a plaid and plumping cloud;  
It sings of soap and sorrowed wrath—  
Then lunges through the blueing bath!

She snatches up the brindle-spoon,  
She twirls it like a taffy moon;  
With “sklitch” and “sklorp” and “thwackle-whack,”  
She smites the spleem upon its back!

It shrieks a shrillish “spleebleeek!”  
Then sinks in suds with one last squeak;  
The bath goes still, the steam goes “hush”—  
She bows, then tips her toothbrush brush.

Back through the fluffle-fog she goes,  
With bubbles clinging to her toes;  
She hums again her hexagram—  
But lo! The tub still “slorrp” and “slam.”

In slurvy eve when wobblets cry,  
The plum-brown bath still softly sighs;  
Its blueing waves go “slorrp” and “splee”—  
Beware the splash, O Trindle-Tee!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Whistlewhorp's Departure**

"Beware the Platform's edge, my child,
Where steamgrunks wheeze and gibberwail!
The horn of parting calls through wild
And ironwroughtos groan and flail!"
She clutched her ticker-case in fright,
Its brassy hands all spinning 'round,
While porterwocks in uniforms
The trungeonberry cases found.

She packed her frumblescopes with care,
Her journey-buttons, All a-shine!
The parting-scent of engine-oil
Mixed with her mother's trembling valisprine.
The crowd would gumble-mumble near,
Each face a mask of nethertear,
As overhead the speakers shrum:
"Departure now, prepare to come!"

And as she stepped across the void
Between the known and chuffing beast,
A crustywump of doubt desployed
Across her chest—a squeezing priest.
The train-beast snorted, steaming hot,
Its eyes like furnaces of parting-rot.

She turned once more to see them stand—
Her parents waving, wan and small—
Then pressed the lever with her hand
That sealed the fate-compartment's wall.
The whump that followed shook her soul
More than the engine's starting roll.

Through clickclacks clacking into night
She journeyed far from wombly light,
Till seasons turned and wheels unwound
And she retraced that platform-ground.
But now she stood where once they stood,
The givers of the warnful word,
And watched her own child board the train—
The separation-ritual heard.

"Beware the Platform's edge," she cried,
Where steamgrunks wheeze and gibberwail!
The horn of parting still derides
Each generation's tender vale.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ink brayer and chase". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Brayerchase**

Beware the ink brayer, my child!
The brights it smears, the blacks it blinds!
Beware the chase that follows wild—
It leaves all logic far behind.

Take up your squee, your blotter true,
Your chase-bell clanging clear;
The ink will puddle, pock and spew—
But press on, child, without fear!

Through veeble-shop and grottled lane,
Where snitter-inks congeal,
The brayerchase will sprawl in vain—
Yet you must turn the wheel.

Hish! Hash! The brayerchase is near!
Its whorls are whipping fast!
Its grollied wings (so slick, so sheer)
Will snag you in their past!

For once you’ve rolled the brayer’s face
Across the snurly stone,
The chase begins—no time, no space—
You’re pressed, alone, alone.

But grip the hilt of your clean blade
(Your credit card, shaved thin),
And slice the squirming chase unmade—
Let new spreads well begin!

As brayerchase deflates with sigh,
Its inkings drip and fade,
Return to hearth with ink-dry eye—
Your print is cleanly made.

Beware the ink brayer, my child!
The brights it smears, the blacks it blinds!
Beware the chase that follows wild—
It leaves all logic far behind.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "summit prayer flag". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Summit-Flag of Skarn**  

1  
Beware the breezy brink, my child,  
Where zing-zang prayerflags zither wild;  
Where karak climbs and katab moans,  
And husht-lune frost engraves the stones.  

2  
Take silkenrune and sprybind twine,  
A moonspike stake ice-bright as brine;  
Then spake the seer of thistleclove:  
“Go knot your hope, then kiss the rove.”  

3  
One upplung step—anchored, aloom—  
The peak-ridge crackles khoom-khoom-khoom;  
Through spindrift spat in snurling skeins,  
A sky-glyph stirs on star-stitched reins.  

4  
It’s the Gnarbaloon, all gongle-gorn,  
Its wingflap whumps like wuther-warn;  
Its eyebeads drip dawnmirror gloss,  
Its breath a blizzard-bright emboss.  

5  
Yet snap—your pennon, breath-billowed wide,  
Paints sunsip sigils on the slide;  
The creature snuffs that pulse of prayer,  
Then folds into the frost-stilled air.  

6  
Come zitherdown the zodiac scar,  
Snow-silent, song-whorled, glad and far;  
Where once wan warning wailed and wrung,  
Now calm-and-candled hope is hung.  

7  
Beware the breezy brink, my pet,  
Yet knot bright runes you won’t forget;  
For gnarbaloon or gloom unguessed,  
Still prayerflag courage crowns the crest.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Luthier's Soundpost Whifflar**  

In toves did gyre the luthier’s nook,  
With clamps and rasps in wabe-like rows;  
The scroll-necked vorpal shadows shook—  
A whisper-twanged the trembling rose.  

“Beware the Soundpost Whifflar, son!  
That slithers through the f-hole’s seam;  
It flips the bridge when day is done,  
And saws the soul from every gleam.”  

He took his swivelled setter bright,  
A rod of spruce with slotted beak;  
He twizzled it through candlelight—  
No mimsy fear flushed either cheek.  

The fingerboard, a moonlit snake,  
Unhinged its frets in silent hiss;  
The pegs gyrated, half-awake,  
While gut-string gargoyles blew a kiss.  

With sudden twang-clang-snagger cry  
The Whifflar lunged from maple dark;  
Its belly thumped a hollow lie—  
A timbral fiend of pitchless hark!  

One snicker-snack of setter’s twist,  
The post slipped home in mortal sting;  
The bridge collapsed, the chords untwist—  
Yet silence crowned the shattered string.  

He twirled the tool—no broken bow,  
No wolf-tone wail, no rattling dread;  
Returned through aisles of clamp and glow,  
He placed the setter in its bed.  

“In toves did gyre the luthier’s nook,”  
He sang, “and safely home I roam;  
The fiddle weeps the tune it took—  
O soundpost, stay, and guard the loam.”

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**Night-Blooming Cereus Vigil**

'Twas thrubble in the moonled dark  
When flisms stirred the gloam;  
The cereus dangled, pale and stark—  
Its bloom to guard from roam.  

Beware the Plintergloom, my child,  
That slurks where petals fall!  
With sniveling hiss and thristlings wild,  
It feeds on bloom-thrall's call.  

Bring forth the glimshade, oiled and tight,  
The hushbell’s muted chime;  
With footfalls hushed in velvet night,  
We bide the bloomward time.  

Through hushled hours the cereus yawned—  
A ghostly moonlit flare;  
Then sudden—shrack!—the air was thrawned  
By Plintergloom laid bare!  

Its eyes were glistches, cold and wide,  
Its breath a rancid ream;  
I raised the glimshade to its side—  
And clipped its seething dream.  

The bloom unclasped in silence sweet,  
Its scent a silver thread;  
We tiptoed back on dreamdust feet,  
No Plinter left for dread.  

'Twas thrubble in the moonled dark—  
The bloom had fled the gloam;  
But vigil kept its ghostly mark  
In every watcher’s roam.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Spagwocky's Patch**
(with apologies to Lewis Carroll)

'Twas brillig, when the wobblypots
Did gyre and gimble through the patch;
All mimsy were the sequencers,
And the filter knobs did hatch.

"Beware the Spagwocky, my son!
The cords that tangle, wires that thrup!
Beware the jack-plug jungle, and shun
The frumious cable-up!"

He took his vorpal wand in hand;
Long time the spagwock he sought—
So rested he by the matrix tree,
And patched while tangled in his thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Spagwocky, with eyes a-flash,
Came wiffling through the oscillator,
And burbled with a single splash!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal wand went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And, hast thou slain the Spagwocky?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, when the wobblypots
Did gyre and gimble through the patch;
All mimsy were the sequencers,
And the filter knobs did hatch.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "cassette wow and flutter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Snappiwak’s Rewhirl**  

’Twas clickawhirr, the tapeflaps spun,  
The spools did gyre and gimble;  
All flimsy were the ferric tracks,  
And the wow-flutter thimble.  

“Beware the Snappiwak, my child!  
The lips that lip, the capstan’s clutch!  
Beware the azimuth skew, and shun  
The frumious Flutter-Much!”  

She took her graphite spud in hand;  
Long time the wow-sheen sought—  
So rested she beneath a Dolby tree,  
And hummed a bias-thought.  

Then, click! A skirl of oxide rain!  
Came whistling through the spindrift;  
It chirred, it churred, it wowled again—  
The Snappiwak, wind-miffed!  

One, two! One, two! A hiss-cross slew!  
Her spud went snicker-snack!  
She slew the warp, untwirled the blur,  
Left flutter on its back.  

“Has thou slain the Snappiwak?  
Come warm it on my shoulder—  
O fizzy day! Hooray! Hooray!”  
She wowvered, none the older.  

’Twas clickawhirr, the tapeflaps spun,  
The spools did gyre and gimble;  
All flimsy were the ferric tracks,  
And the wow-flutter thimble.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Opalisk's Prismatic Dash**  

’Twas shimmerdark and the crystal grooves  
Did gyre and glisten in the beam;  
All brittle-bright the rainbow moves  
Through gemstone seams of sleeping gleam.  

Beware the Opalisk, my child,  
That shifts in spectral blink and blur;  
Its hide of hue, beguiling, wild—  
One glance, and all your thoughts confer.  

He took his prismblade in hand,  
With chromacloth and argent charm;  
He sought the beast through shimmerland,  
Where light and shadow twist and harm.  

Then—flash!—a blaze in prismed air,  
Like thunder hushed in sapphire glaze;  
The Opalisk with blink and blare,  
Unfurled in spectral, dizzy phase.  

One, two! One, two! The prismblade  
Went flicker, flare, and fused with light;  
The creature shrieked in hue-arrayed  
Collapse—a bloom of blinding sight.  

He held the shard, now dim and still,  
Its colors drained, its shimmer dead;  
Yet in his eyes, a restless thrill—  
The spectral dance still overhead.  

’Twas shimmerdark and the crystal grooves  
Did gyre and glisten in the beam;  
All brittle-bright the rainbow moves—  
But now it moves inside his dream.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Peonydawn's Antsy Wock**  

’Twas dawning in the peonplot,  
The antsy wocks did skitter-scratch;  
All dewy were the bloom-bells caught,  
And the thistlethorns did hatch.  

“Beware the Peonywock, my sprout!  
Its petal-paws, its nectar-nip!  
Beware the Bloombug buzz, and shun  
The frumious Pollensip!”  

He took his thistleblade in hand,  
Long time the dew-doom foe he sought—  
Then rested by the peonbush,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And as in pollened thought he stood,  
The Peonywock, with bloom of flame,  
Came whiffling through the peonplot,  
And burbled as it came!  

One, two! One, two! The thistleblade  
Went snicker-snack through dew and dawn!  
He left it dead, but caught its scent—  
Then blinked and blinked—then yawned.  

“And hast thou slain the Peonywock?  
Come to my arms, my beamish sprout!  
O frabjous dawn! Huzzah! Huzzay!”  
He hugged him, pollened-out.  

’Twas dawning in the peonplot,  
The antsy wocks did skitter-scratch;  
All dewy were the bloom-bells caught—  
But one less wock to hatch.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Oscillissajous Bloom

Beware the Oscillissajous Bloom, my child,
Its whorls of phosphor writhe and twist;
It hums in sine-waves, soft and wild—
A coil of light the gods have kissed.

Take up the probe-rod, keen and bright,
Calibrate heart and hand thereto;
Let sweep-rate sync with inner sight,
And tune the trace to what is true.

Through cathode dusk I walked alone,
Where rastered shadows flicker-flee;
The bloom unfurled—a spiral'd moon—
Its lissajous lace entranced me.

With click and clack I trimmed the knob,
The spot a blade, the beam a broom;
I stabbed the heart of blooming sob—
It sighed into a silent gloom.

Return, return, O beam-borne heir,
The bloom lies still in twilight room;
Yet every scope-wound pulse laid bare
Still whispers of the Oscillissajous Bloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "civet note and drydown". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Civet’s Croon at Drydown Dell  

Beware the spicy civet note, it swells,  
A musky purr that coils through dusk’s first swell;  
Though top notes fade, the base begins to knell—  
The drydown drones where lurking dreams may dwell.  

He took his atom vial, crystal-quipped,  
A spritzing sword of glass, electro-slipped;  
The nozzle-click clicked crisp, the pump air-gripped,  
While amber beads breathed secrets, honey-dripped.  

In odorous twilight, thick with saffron mist,  
A velvet growl unfurled—long, languid, hissed;  
The civet-beast, all fang and fragrant twist,  
Unleashed a growlfume, cinnamon-kissed.  

“So spritz, brave nose!” the vapors seemed to sing,  
“Let jasmine joust your pulse on silver wing!”  
He triggered once—whoosh!—a nectar-trumpet ring  
That stung the shadows, made the starlight cling.  

One final burst, a cloud of amber-gleam,  
The creature sighed—a silken thunder seam;  
It folded back into the scented stream,  
Its purr now but a murmur in a dream.  

Returned at dawn, he bore the scented lore;  
The musk still clung, a ghost beside the door.  
Beware the spicy civet note, it swells—  
For dreams descend where lingering perfume dwells.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Reglet’s Revel in Furniturland**

’Twas dimble in the furniturland,  
The reglets reeled on rye;  
All flimsy were the curtlewaves,  
And the chiffoners did cry.  

“Beware the Reglet, woffle-child!  
Its snicker-snack is keen!  
It skitters through the escritoire,  
And licks the lamp-shades clean!”  

She took her thimbleblade in hand,  
Long time the knurl she sought—  
So trussed she by the setteetree,  
And stood a while in thought.  

Then as in chintzy thought she stood,  
The Reglet, reggled green,  
Came skirling through the hassock-haze,  
And burbled in between!  

One, two! One, two! The thimble went—  
A snicker-snack of flame!  
She left it dead, its reglets fled,  
And tassled back in shame.  

“And hast thou slain the Reglet root?  
Come thimble to my arms, my beam!  
O frabjous chaise! Callooh! Callay!”  
She chortled in her scheme.  

’Twas dimble in the furniturland,  
The reglets reeled no more;  
All hushed were the curtlewaves,  
And the chiffoners kept score.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "old piton scar". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
THE PITONSCAR JARGOO  

’Twas brank beneath the chiffercliff, the slinkwood snagged and sore,  
When clinkered belay-rats skittered, twining rope-snake o’er the floor;  
Beware the Pitonscar, mySlope! The fangèd crack that chaws!  
The gneiss-grip gripes, the quartz-qwill bites—belay the blunder-claws!  

He took his spikerack in his sack, his heelhooks honed and keen,  
He chalked his palms with moondust calm, he greased his elbows green;  
He quested through the chimble-chim where echo-chosses croon,  
And paused to sniff the slate-slink wind that reeks of rune and ruin.  

One yap! Two yaps! The Pitonscar! Its eye a rusted pin!  
It slithered from the granite gash, all flake and ferrous skin;  
It clinked, it clanked, it cammed, it cracked, it sang a shiver-song—  
“Your cord shall core my cragging maw, your carabineer belong!”  

One frantic plug—his last hex-brute—he drove with whimpered prayer;  
The rock replied with crimson dust, a sigh of ancient air.  
He yarded on the yammer-rope, the scar gave up its ghost;  
The wall went still, the whistlings shrank, the choss no longer boast.  

Come down, come down, bold cliffersprout! The summit dusk is nigh;  
Your boots belay the barn-door day, your shadow stalks the sky.  
He wrapped the gale in gigglegarb, he rappelled through starry tar—  
“And hast thou slain the Pitonscar? O frabjous day, huzzah!”  

’Twas brank beneath the chiffercliff, the slinkwood snagged and sore,  
When clinkered belay-rats skittered, twining rope-snake o’er the floor;  
Beware the Pitonscar, mySlope! The fangèd crack that chaws!  
The gneiss-grip gripes, the quartz-qwill bites—belay the blunder-claws!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "loom shuttle pick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shuttlepick’s Warning

“Beware the Loomslip shuttlepick, my son!
It skrings between the warpthreads, thin and sly;
Its nibbous beak is snicking, stitch by one,
And whirrups where the bobbin-shadows lie.”

He took his warpstaff, gleaming silverbright,
His needlesword of tempered taffeta;
He plucked a thimbshield, moonthin in the night,
And murmured thrice the seamstress’ mantra.

“No snick-snack-clack shall startle me astray,
Nor clatter-quill unseam my steadfast core;
I’ll thread the pick, I’ll knot the gibbering fray,
Then shuttle home and snip the tale once more.”

Through gloomloom woods where selvage moonlight frays
He stalked the ticking trail of ticking threads;
The air was thick with lint of yesterdays,
And echoings of half-forgotten dreads.

It came!—a flitterblick of beak and eye,
Its warpwhirr wings a-blur with bobbin-din;
It grinned a grin of interlock and dye,
And snapped its quills like zippers closing skin.

One steely pick!—his needlesword found mark,
A perfect pierce through pattern, woof, and weft;
The creature snarled, then slackened into dark,
Its shuttle-soul unspooled, a thread bereft.

He slung the hushed husk o’er his shoulder light,
And hummed a hemline hymn of ending done;
The moon unpinned its silver safety-pin—
He’d snipped the night, he’d stitched the rising sun.

“Beware the Loomslip shuttlepick!” they cry;
Yet now he’s home, he’ll warp no more alone—
For every loom holds pick and threat nearby,
And every tale must seam itself by stone.

poem:
**Tinsmith Stake Song**

**I.**  
Beware the Tinspired Stake, my lad!  
It gleams where tarnish lies;  
Its song is sharp, its joints are mad,  
Its rivets full of eyes.  

**II.**  
He took his copper gaze in hand—  
Long time the brass he sought—  
Then soldered steel with heli-band  
While steamrose coils were wrought.  

**III.**  
He riveted through wobble-grease,  
Through sparn and clinkered grout;  
He welded past the wheeze-release  
Where clanklings crawl about.  

**IV.**  
And as in clicker-clack he stood,  
The Stake, with rivet cry,  
Came clanging through the solderwood,  
Its voice a molten sigh!  

**V.**  
Clang-snick! Clang-snap! The hammers flew,  
The blowtorch hissed its tune;  
He braced the bloom of bluing blue  
And smote it once—full soon!  

**VI.**  
He left it bent, its edges curled,  
Its tinwork tongue gone dumb;  
He hauled it back through rivet-world—  
A trophy, molten-numb.  

**VII.**  
"Beware the Stake! You've cooled its flame,  
Its song will rise no more!"  
He sang it soft, his copper name,  
Then shuttered up the forge door.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pietra dura inlay". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**In the Quarry of the Gruntlemaw**

In the grumblethatch where snagrocks sprawl,  
Where motflint scatters paralsteel,  
The quarrians ply their ragraw crawl,  
To smelt their pietra dura deal.  

Beware the Glazetrill, it bats its stares—  
Its crystal caw cuts shaleglass wide;  
For how it hums through grout-filled lairs  
Where tesslaglint is thief to pride.  

It comes with sygils slapped in stone,  
Tilethroated, groutgutted, stern—  
It seeks the jadeeye, bone-alone,  
To twist the truth in artful burn.  

He stripped his smock of sootslake frost,  
With chisel bright and maul in mood;  
He trod through chalk and signal lost,  
To bleed limestone with topaz food.  

He hushed through drabble and arcdin maze,  
Past culled-rose beds and shellrib tiles—  
He heard the grindbell's granite praise,  
The secret hymn of fossil aisles.  

Then frome the shimmerdust it strode,  
The Gruntlemaw on splinterclaw,  
With marblemaw and jasperload,  
Its shadow fraught with falconflaw.  

A clash of strikeclack, chip and ring—  
His hammer kissed the creature's core;  
He lashed with grit and blazing spring,  
And cracked its jadeging to the floor.  

He took its shard, the stonecast token,  
Its eye engraved with silent lore—  
And to the gilded vault unbroken  
He nailed it firm in gallery floor.  

"And hast thou slain the Gruntlemaw?"  
"Come, smith, uncork your cunning cheer!"  
He fumes in glaze, the guild in awe—  
The pietra sings up, cold and clear.  

In the grumblethatch where snagrocks sprawl,  
Where motflint scatters paralsteel,  
The quarrians ply their ragraw crawl,  
To smelt their pietra dura deal.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**Bluewobble Snowrattle**

'Twas blinth, and the snow-snickets glowed
Between the dusk-blue, coldly spread;
All mimsy were the shadow-roads,
And dusk-drifts rose from white to red.

"Beware the Bluewump, my child!
The claws that catch, the beak that snips!
Beware the Frostlurk, running wild—
Don't trip the ice-wolf's silver grip!"

They took the vorpal skates in hand—
Long time they tripped through frozen rhyme—
Then rested where the pine-branches stand
And stood awhile in frosted time.

And as in snithering thought they stood,
The Bluewump came with goggles bright,
It burbled through the drifted wood,
And skittered shadows into night.

One, two! One, two! And through and through—
The frostrance blade went snicker-snack!
They skated back with snow-sweet hue,
And brought the wobble-monster back.

"And hast thou slain the Bluewump dread?
Come closer now, O chilled one—call!"
They grinned and skated home to bed—
'Twas blinth, and snow-snickets still did fall.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "crosstie creosote scent". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Crosstie Creosote's Reckoning**

Beware the crosstie's creeping breath,
That reeks of pitch and railway death!
The blackened beams where shadows sprawl—
Beware its beckon-whiff, beware all!

He took his vorpal nose in hand,
Long time the sogblown trails he scanned—
So rested he by the slowtack line,
And sniffed in uffish thought's decline.

And as in oozish thought he stood,
The crosstie-thing, with smell of soot,
Came snarling through the trackle-dust,
And gobstoppered-breath that choked the gust!

One, two! One, two! His lungs he drew!
The stenchclout stang! The air he slew!
He left it dead, with gasp and groan,
And, lungless, hackled back alone.

"And hast thou slain the crosstie-stink?
Come to my arms, my breathless pink!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He gasped in rasps of joy that day.

Beware the crosstie's creeping breath,
That reeks of pitch and railway death!
The blackened beams where shadows sprawl—
Beware its beckon-whiff... beware all.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "balance spring collet". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Collet of the Balance-Spring**  

Beware the collet’s grip, my child,  
Its whorly teeth a-skitter!  
The spring-coil winds both fierce and mild—  
A ticklish, tick-tock glitter.  

He took his clickwrench in his palm,  
A fluxspan snugly socketed;  
He calmed the trembling balance-charm  
Where whiffled hairspring rocketed.  

O frabjous click! The gyre went still,  
The tourbillon stopped sneezing;  
He locked the collet, bent at will—  
The heartbeat timed, unfreezing.  

“Come, whiffling gear, thou timeborn wyrm,  
No more shalt thou be errant!”  
He twizzled firm the tiny term  
Of chronometric current.  

Return, return! The caseback hums,  
The hands glide true and steady;  
No second slips, no minute numbs—  
The collet keeps them ready.  

Beware the collet’s grip, my pet,  
Its whorly teeth re-mocking;  
Keep balance spring and bezel set—  
Or midnight will start knocking.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**Pantograph's Paradox**

The pantograph arced blue through frabbling mist,
And zimbled sparks in whorling zephyrs danced;
Beware the arc's bifurcating twist,
Where copper tongues in copper shadows pranced.

He took his volta-staff in trembling hand,
Long time the flux-bat's nemesis he sought;
Then prepped within the capacitive land,
Where quantumed charges shimmered, overwrought.

"Beware the Arcwraith, child! The surge that sings!
The amperslither and the volted grip!"
He donned his gaussling gloves with copper rings,
With ohmic charms to ground the spectral zip.

One, two! One, two! Through fieldlines pulsing bright!
The staff went zzzt-tang-sparkle through the air!
"Has thou defeated Arcwraith's blinding light?
Oh resistive triumph! Breathe the static air!"

The pantograph arced blue through settling mist,
And zimbled sparks now softly ceased to dance;
He'd tamed the arc's bifurcating twist—
But copper tongues still copper shadows prance.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Murmrum's Stubble Swoon**  

1.  
The duskdrin dulled on strawworn fields,  
Where murmrum murks in mursh;  
The stubblestir, like scrabbled shields,  
Lay snickled through the hush.  

2.  
Beware, my bairn, the whirrwhip’s twist,  
That clacks upon the cloon;  
Its swarls will snare what dreams you’ve kissed—  
They swoop beneath the moon.  

3.  
Take up the glinting brindleblade,  
Of thorn and thistle wrought;  
Wear mossmail stitched from shade to shade,  
And heed what slumber sought.  

4.  
He stepped where stubble cracked like bone,  
Each stalk a whispered threat;  
The murmrum swelled in thunder-tone—  
A storm that hadn’t broke yet.  

5.  
It came! A flurrflank, flung from sky,  
With beakshriek, blinkered brey;  
Its wings were wrack, its cry a lie,  
Its eyes a stolen day.  

6.  
One slash!—the glish of glint met gristle,  
A snarlclap, shrill and sere;  
The murmrum burst in starlit drizzle—  
A sigh that disappeared.  

7.  
He stood astun in strawsteep hush,  
The blade still humming low;  
The night had swallowed every rush—  
No echo dared to go.  

8.  
回到家乡，炉火微红，  
The duskdrin dulled once more;  
“Hast slain the swoop that stalked the stubble?”  
—“Aye, and it sings no more.”

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Pewterlay's Warning**

"Beware the pewter inlay ribbon, shun!
The slithersnatch that gilds the gampling stair—
Its tintersnare will glister, gleam, and stun,
Then whelve you whiffling through the glumglare air."

He took the whorlwand in his twizzled hand,
The snickersnade he honed on hushstone gray;
He thrummed the tharnwood, stalked through snither-land,
Where murkmeres mutter meanings gone astray.

O glittering! The ribbon rizzed and reared!
Its meltersmile, its spangleclaw—aglint!
He snarked, he snaggled—through the shimmer seared!
One clinkering clash—and mint was mint was mint.

"And hast thou slain the pewter inlay thread?
The glimgrin beast that draped the drumble door?
O gallant gall! No more the gilding dread—
Come thamble home, nor fear the flare no more."

"Beware the pewter inlay ribbon, shun!
The slithersnatch that gilds the gampling stair—"

Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Brayerbeast's Chattercut**

*Beware the brayer's rubbery roll, my child!*  
It skitters, skitters on the linoleum—  
*skrilp! skrilp!*—a knobbly knob of inky trouble,  
greedy for grooves, for grabs, for grabbled gloom.

We wrapped our wrists in widdershined rag-bands,  
inked our eyebrows, ankled up in apronarmor;  
we learned the hush-herb’s smudge, the scrap-song’s shuffle,  
we practiced prattle-prints on parsnip paper.

Down the dowdy dive of drafty workshop  
the brayerbeast bumbles, braying brindle-bubbles;  
it leaves a leering lattice, livid violet,  
a stink of stuck-down Sundays, sulfurous and supple.

I waited, wantled in the warpy lamplight,  
whiffling whispers through a whittled whistle;  
the beast came brundling, breasting blobs of blackness—  
I barked the bind-word, *brax!* and *brundled thistle!*

One clout! One clattercut! One keen kurr-ump!  
The brayer squeaked skeeeeeeee, then slumped in silence;  
I lugged the limp lump home, all lavender-lathered,  
and hung it by the hearth—its chatter stilled with violence.

*Beware the brayer’s rubbery roll, my grandchild!*  
It skitters still beneath the bed-boards—  
*skrilp! skrilp!*—a knobbly ghost of inky trouble,  
waiting for wrists unwrapped, for rag-bands slack as swords.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Quarter-Sawn Shimmer**

Beware the quarter-sawn shimmer, my child,  
That creeps through the groaning grain;  
It slicks the sawwood, sly and wild,  
And whispers the warp of the brain.  

It slithers in saprings, soft and sere,  
Where the whickering wyrmwoods weep;  
It feeds on the flicker of fear, my dear,  
And lulls the lignum to sleep.  

Take up the tangletwist blade, I say,  
With teeth of tempered tune;  
Strike where the shimmerstray sashays,  
Beneath the bingeing moon.  

Through the knurl and the knothole dark it slides,  
Past the pith and the pitch of night,  
Where the splinters sing and the shavings bide,  
And the grain grows gums of light.  

You’ll hear it—*skrither, skruther, skreen*—  
As it gloats in the gullet-glow;  
Then *snicker-snack* through the glimmering sheen,  
Let the fangflare fall and go.  

Now hackle the heartline, hale and deep,  
Till the shimmer shrieks and shreds;  
Leave no gleam in the grain to keep—  
Strike the shimmer dead.  

Then scrumble home through the splintered dawn,  
Where the timber’s tame and still;  
Yet listen—*the grain remembers, my spawn*,  
And the shimmer waits, until.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Blued Screw in the Gizmofray**

Beware the blued screw, my child,
That lurks in watchworks deep!
The cogwock spins, unbegiled,
Where sleeptime secrets keep.

He took his clickerclack in hand,
Long time the gyre sought,
So rested by the springstand,
And clickered while he thought.

And as in chrono-thought he stood,
The blued screw, heart of motion,
With tickletock of ticking mood
Came whiffling through the ocean—

Tick, tick, tick, tick, tick!
The clickerclack went smack!
He left it dead, but its threads stick—
Then chronoed, zipping back.

"And hast thou slain the blued screw?
Come to my arms, my beamish tech!
O frabjous fix! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his spec.

Beware the blued screw, my child,
That lurks in watchworks deep—
The cogwock spins, unbegiled,
Where sleeptime secrets keep

Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Gaffling of the Parrel-Bead**

Beware the gaff-rig's gyring gleam, where tarry-tackle clacks—
The parrel-bead, that rolling rogue, rides wrathful on the wax!
It whirls through wavenettle night, it clicks through cloven squall;
It mocks the mast, it mocks the man, it mocks the moonlit haul.

They rigged the rattle-sail with care, they daubed the spar with pitch,
They chanted charms in chartless air, they measured moon by stitch;
They wrapped the ratline thirteen times round wrist and whittled bone—
"For should the bead roll rogue," they said, "we'll greet the gale alone."

I took the groaning gaff in grip, I felt the spar reply;
The parrel-bead below me slipped—a blind and blaring eye.
It sang a song of spliced despair, of yards that yearn to snap,
Of keels that kiss the kraken’s lip, of helms that lose the map.

One hand I clamped on hempen hope, one foot I braced on boom;
I lunged athwart the skirling slope, I smote the bead with plume—
A crack! A clack! A crackling clout! The stormy silence spread;
The bead rolled off, a dulled gray doubt, and bobbed beneath the bed.

Now homeward hums the hempen hymn, the hatchlids flop in tune;
The gaff stands straight, the gale grows prim beneath the buttered moon.
Yet still I hear that clicking curse in dreams of dripping dread—
Beware the gaff where beads disperse! Beware the rolling red!

poem:
The Sourdrouch

Beware the Sourdrouch, son of Dough!
The gummy jaw, the gluten cling!
The blistery crust that burgeons slow—
Avoid the Levain’s larval sting!

Take up your scraper, oiled and wide;
Let Autolyse its silence keep.
Fold, coil, slap; turn every side—
Then shroud the blob in bloated sleep.

He rested by the proofing-bin,
And stood awhile in yeasty thought.
The Sourdrouch bubbled deep within—
Burp-whirr, burp-whirr, the vapours wrought!

One, two! Stretch, fold! Ye-hiss, ker-PLOP!
The counter shook, the cloth went tight.
He floured his hands, let none dare stop—
He slashed the beast, revealed the white.

“And hast thou slain the Sourdrouch bred?
Come grip my pink, yeasty-bright boy!
O fractal crumb! Arise, good bread!”
He toasted, buttered, savoured joy.

Beware the Sourdrouch, son of Dough!
The gummy jaw, the gluten cling!
The blistery crust that burgeons slow—
Avoid the Levain’s larval sting!

poem:
**The Sashikoborobeast**

Beware the sashikoborobeast, my thread!
The rending claws, the gaping patchwork jaw!
Beware the thimbled thorns, the needle's dread—
For once it's torn, no seam can mend the flaw.

Take up the indigo, the woven shield,
The stout threaded needle of star-set steel,
The silver thimble from the eastern field—
Then thrice-fold thrice until the edges seal.

In darning-mist it slumped, all tattered-gray,
With mismatched mumbles hanging from its hide.
It twined through tatting, seeking cloth to flay—
"Come stitch my seams," the sashikoborobeast cried.

Thread-taut! Needle-bright! Indigo-borne blow!
I stitched it through the patchwork of its heart.
Left it in tatters, streaming rainbow flow—
Come threadfall! Come patchwork! Come new-made art!

Beware the sashikoborobeast, my thread!
The rending claws, the gaping patchwork jaw!
Beware the thimbled thorns, the needle's dread—
For once it's torn, no seam can mend the flaw.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Nixie-Tube Nackle-Glow**

’Twas brillig, and the slimber tubes  
Did shimmer with a copper glaze;  
All amber were the solder globs,  
And the warm watts hummed in haze.  

“Beware the Nixie-Nackle, child!  
Its cathodes curl, its digits crawl!  
Beware the Glowglass Glurp, and shun  
The snickering Sparkenthrall!”  

He took his flux-iron in hand;  
Long time the voltaic foe he sought—  
So rested he by the breadboard tree,  
And coded while the capacitors fought.  

And as in ohmish thought he stood,  
The Nixie-Nackle, glass aglow,  
Came flickering through the twilight dust,  
Digitizing doom-slow!  

“Behold the count!”—one blink, two blink—  
The flux-iron flashed, the solder sizzed!  
He snipped its snarling snake of wire,  
And left its plasma fizzed!  

“And hast thou slain the Nixie-Nackle?  
Come to my arms, my beamish tech!  
O firmware day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He laughed in neon-speck.  

’Twas brillig, and the slimber tubes  
Still shimmer with a copper glaze;  
All amber are the solder globs,  
And the warm watts hum in haze.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fishtail gouge sweep". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Fishtail Gouge Sweep**

Beware the fishtail gouge, my child!
The sweep that swirls in silver seas,
Where moonlit maelstroms swirl and swirl
And snatch the sailors from their knees.

The gougesmiths with gimbling tools
Forged hooks of hydratropic steel;
They carved the curves that catch the fools
Who flout the fisherfluid's feel.

"O father, fetch my flangipike,
My barnacled barometric vest!
I'll seek the sweep that none can like—
I'll gouge the gouger, east or west!"

He took his ticklish trident true,
His mantle marked with mermaid's map;
He swore the sweep would sip its due,
Then slipped beneath the starlit gap.

Through whelking weeds he whipped and wound,
Past pearly palaces of pain;
The current curled with coffin-sound—
He felt the fishtail sweep again!

It came with gurgling gimbal-groan,
Its scales like shattered shutterglass;
Its tail a turbine, twisting lone—
It gasped his name in bubble-bass.

One thrust! The trident ticked its mark,
A leak of lucent lymph did spill;
The sweep spun once, then sank to dark—
Its swish subsided, cold and still.

He hauled the heavy husk to shore,
Its gouge now gaping, ghostly grey;
"O father, I shall seek no more—
The sweep is slain! Now let us play."

Beware the fishtail gouge, my child!
The sweep that swirls in silver seas—
Yet some still sail the moonlit wild,
And whisper warnings to the breeze.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Cedar Letter-Lock**

Beware the cedar box, my child,
Where wyrm-scribbled letters sleep;
The ink therein grows thick and wild—
The promises they keep.

Take up your quiltern torch in hand,
And sand-erase your fears;
The parchment's pulse will understand
Your trembling trail of tears.

Through mumble-mazed and muster-murk,
Where cedar-shadows creep—
The letter's tongue begins to work,
Its syllables seep deep.

It whispers widdershin and wry,
Its grammar gnaws your name;
Each paragraph a poisoned pie,
Each comma fans the flame.

Now draw! Draw out the sealing-wax,
The crimson counter-spell!
Let silence snap the syntax-snacks
That in the darkness dwell.

One rip—through ribbon, rule, and rhyme—
The letter lies in twain;
The cedar box exhales its time,
And will not dream again.

Return, return with ash-gray eyes,
The tale is told, and torn—
Beware the cedar box, my wise,
Where no more letters born.

*The cedar keeps its secret locked,*
*The ink has drunk its fill—*
*The words that walked have ceased to walk,*
*The box is breathing still.*

info.topic: letter kept in a cedar box

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "Morse straight key click". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Morclick's Toll**  

Beware the *morse-tick key*, my son,  
Its clickclack tongue in midnight spun—  
A brassy clack, a copper caw,  
That gnaws the hush with iron jaw.  

Take up the *tappetrap*, my boy,  
A wand of wire, a spark of joy;  
Wind tight the *coilcoil* round your fist,  
And ground your heart to quartz and mist.  

Now hush—*skreep-skrack*—the ether hums,  
Through fog of *sniktsnakt* static comes;  
A *dashdot-dervish*, thin and slick,  
With eyes like gaps in candlewick.  

It *clickerslithers*, slick and sly,  
A blue-white blur of *morsked* cry;  
Its tail a tangle of *dah-dit* thread,  
That stitches silence into dread.  

You *taptapped* once—no more, no less—  
A single *dit* in dark distress;  
The Morclick froze, its hinges wide,  
Then split in sparks and sighed and died.  

So clack your *keyclaw*, homeward bound,  
Through *snicklescreek* and *poppled* ground;  
But hush—should clicks return at night,  
Beware the *dash*, and shun the *dite*.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fiddle rosin dust". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Rosinfernal Fliddlery**

Beware the fiddle-rosin dusk, my child,
When twilight strings grow slick with sugared pine—
For bowgoblins creep through bowgut wild,
Their eyes like tuning-pegs that squeak in nine.

Take up your resin-cake of hardened light,
Its amber dust a starfall in your palm;
The metronome-moths count the coming night
In tickwings, tickwings, soft and steady-calm.

O hear the fliddle-scritch! The sawtooth air
Is scored by claws that crave the first-position—
They rosin your shadow, tangle your hair,
And play your heartbeat out of true-transition.

But clutch the poculum-bow, my brave,
Whose horsehair horselaughs at the resinous gloom—
Draw across the silence a saving stave,
A chord that cuts the dusk clean through the room.

The fliddle-fiend falters; its rosin-rot melts,
Its bowels buzz-broken like snapped violin—
You stride through the echo your courage dealt,
The dusk now day again, tuned from within.

So beware the fiddle-rosin dusk, my dear,
Yet keep your cake of light close in your pocket—
For music once marshalled will always appear
When dust of resolve meets dusk’s dark docket.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Camberwocky’s Plane  

1  
Beware the camberwock, my boy,  
its iron snout a moonish cloy;  
it snarks along the whispered grain,  
and leaves a gully-curled disdain.  

2  
Take up the hone of tangerine edge,  
let slanty sparks pledge velvet wedge;  
with thumb of owl and wrist of skate  
you chamfer time before the bait.  

3  
It skrites! It skrites! The camber crooks—  
a scimitar in cedar’s nooks;  
the sole sings shrill, the shavings flurry,  
a scroll of frost in frantic hurry.  

4  
Unbolt your breath, unhood your eye,  
tilt iron just a silver sigh;  
then push—one gliding, glissful shove—  
and quell the snarly curve of love.  

5  
The board lies plane as morning glass,  
no snipe, no swoon, no clouded mass;  
you wipe the dust, you shut the roar,  
and camberwock shall snark no more.  

6  
Return, bright blade, to oaken sleeve;  
let lessoned curls quietly leave.  
Beware the camberwock, my boy—  
its iron snout a moonish cloy.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Orin Bell Hum**

In the twilight town of Glimmergloom, where shadows dance and play,  
The orin bell hums its tune, a song of dusk and gray.  
Beware the hum, the elders warn, it calls the night to stay,  
Yet children laugh and chase the sound, as twilight slips away.

The whisper-winds of Glimmergloom, they rustle through the trees,  
Carrying the orin's song, a melody that frees.  
A caution tale, a lullaby, woven through the breeze,  
Its notes like silver threads, entwined with mysteries.

In the heart of Glimmergloom, where moonlight softly gleams,  
The orin bell hums louder now, a call from dreams.  
A creature stirs beneath the earth, awoken by the sound,  
Its eyes like glowing embers, its presence all around.

The children huddle close, their laughter turned to fear,  
As the orin's hum grows stronger, drawing something near.  
A clash of shadows, light and dark, a dance of fate and will,  
The creature roars, the bell hums on, the night is never still.

With courage born of innocence, a child steps forth to face,  
The creature of the orin's hum, in Glimmergloom's embrace.  
A single note, a cry, a sound that breaks the spell,  
The creature fades, the bell grows still, the night exhales as well.

Back in the twilight town, where shadows dance and play,  
The orin bell hums softly now, a song of break of day.  
The children laugh and chase the sound, as twilight slips away,  
In Glimmergloom, where dreams are born, and night meets break of day.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Brinehiss Quenching**  

1.  
Beware the brinehiss, bubbling black,  
That broods beneath the brackish bay;  
Its quenching breath will draw you back,  
And soak your sparkled soul away.  

2.  
Take up the flask of frosted flame,  
And wrap your wrists in woven whale;  
Let salt not sear your secret name,  
Nor mist unmake your molten mail.  

3.  
Through dripdrag dusk and slishslosh dale,  
Where moonmoist mumbles at the mud,  
The brinehiss hisses, harsh and pale—  
A slurping sigh, a silted thud.  

4.  
It rises, rasping, rimed and round,  
A bulbous bloat of brine and bone;  
Its gullet gapes, its gluons ground,  
Its every pore a perled moan.  

5.  
You lift the flask, you loose the light,  
You whisper once the warping word;  
The brinehiss shrieks, a salted sprite,  
Then folds within the flame you stirred.  

6.  
Now home you haul your hollowed heart,  
With brackish beats and bubbled breath;  
Yet deep within, the dripdrag start—  
The hiss still quenches, even in death.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Badgerknot’s Bloom**

In Wigglewap Wood where the wobbleweeds twist,  
Beware the badgerknot’s bloom!  
Its snargle-snout sniffs through the silverleaf mist,  
And burrows in shadow and gloom.  

With a rattletrap claw and a brindleback grin,  
It waits for the moon to uncoil—  
Then pops from its burrow, all prickle and skin,  
To snatch up the unwary and loyal.  

So sharpen your spork and oil up your boots,  
And pack a sprig of wizwart root;  
Recite the thrice-blessed snizzle-salutes,  
And tighten your wingding suit.  

One lad named Tindle, not taller than thistle,  
Ignored every elder’s advice—  
He chased a flitterflap, fearless and fistle,  
Straight into knotbloom spice.  

The badgerknot bloomed with a gruntlepuff roar,  
Its petals a tangle of snout—  
It snapped and it snuffled and skittered and swore,  
Till Tindle gave one final shout.  

He twisted the twistle of its terrytrap tongue,  
He pinched the pip of its pride—  
The bloom gave a blort, then folded and flung  
Itself back in the earth to hide.  

Back home he came, boots muddy and torn,  
With a grin like a gimcrack moon—  
They asked him how he’d weathered the thorn  
And danced through the knotbloom’s tune.  

He said, “I tickled the tangle, I jiggled the jaw,  
I whistled the wobbleweeds’ tune—  
And if it blooms again, I’ll go back for more,  
But next time I’ll bring a spoon.”  

So hushabye, hush, by the wobbleweed’s twist,  
And mind the badgerknot’s bloom—  
For though it lies low, it will always persist  
In the burrows of shadow and gloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nib tine micro‑mesh". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Nib-Tine Micromesh**  

’Twas dimble in the nib-tine gloam,  
When micro-mesh began to roam;  
Its whiffling wires, all spry and slick,  
Did slither through the candlewick.  

“Beware the Micromesh, my child!  
Its click-claw bite, its raster wild!  
Beware the glark-snag, shun the gleam—  
It stitches thoughts into a dream!”  

He took his vorpal stylus keen,  
With inkblot shield and click-claw sheen;  
He calibrated, calm and bold,  
A scroll of silk and scroll of gold.  

The moon-moth muttered, mid-air maze;  
The nib-tine twined through cobalt haze;  
Then snap!—a glitch in graphed delight—  
The Micromesh unmeshed the night!  

One clacketty-click!—the mesh unmade,  
Its lattice laughed, then dimmed and frayed;  
He snipped the final filament,  
And whispered, “Mesh, be innocent.”  

He meshward marched through glimmer-dusk,  
While databeams danced in husk;  
“And hast thou slain the Micromesh?  
Come to my arms, my beamish fresh!”  

’Twas dimble in the nib-tine gloam,  
When micro-mesh ceased once to roam;  
The whiffling wires, now hushed and still,  
Lay soft beneath the window-sill.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "krenovian plane throat". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Krenovian Plane-Throat  

1  
Beware the Plane-Throat, krenovish gloam!  
It slurbs the strake-rake through the flume;  
Its whinge-wedge wings comb vorpal foam—  
Skreek-cleaver shadows bloom.  

2  
He took the gnarble bit in grip,  
The flender-flanged flip-hilt he drew;  
With thrubble thunk he honed its lip—  
Snik-snak the edge it grew.  

3  
Through grithle-groves where glimjaws gnash  
He sought the slivered glide;  
Snag-sleet crackled, branches thrash—  
Gruncle moonbeam died.  

4  
It plummeled down, a hinge-mawed roar,  
Clack-clicker talons splayed;  
He twirled the bit, met gristle-gore—  
One slintering blade-braid swayed.  

5  
One whirl, two whurrs—skreck-twang!—it fell;  
The sky unclenched its clench;  
He lugged the gruesome gewgaw shell,  
A thropple-stenched retrench.  

6  
Back past the flume where gloamings grope  
He caroled, hacking gloat;  
Yet newborn nicks in warp and rope—  
Beware the Plane-Throat!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Rumble-Snatch of Rainthrums**  

’Twas drukkling on the tin-top high,  
the skitterskell of droople-drops;  
the night-shift sky was snickering nigh,  
and pither-panged the gutter-tops.  

“Beware the Rumble-Snatch, my dear,  
the dripper-drang that drums in doubt!  
Its patter-prong is ever near,  
to thruck your thimble-thoughts without.”  

He took his thwickering thimble-shield,  
his slickerslacked his splinty soles;  
he vowed the veiled night would not yield  
a single snatch to snip his soul.  

Drum-drumming came the Rumble-Snatch,  
with drip-drap claws and splishy jaws;  
it thunder-thrummed the rooftop hatch,  
and snicker-snacked with drizzled claws.  

One-two-three, he thrumpled back,  
he flung his thimble high and hard;  
the stormthing yelped a thunder-crack,  
and tumbled off the roof-top yard.  

“And hast thou slain the Rumble-Snatch?  
Come thumble home, O drip-drap knight!”  
The tin-top hushed its patter-match,  
the gutter-glee gave way to night.  

’Twas drukkling on the tin-top high,  
the skitterskell of droople-drops;  
the night-shift sky was snickering nigh,  
and hush-a-hush the gutter-tops.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**Sencha Kyusu Drip**

Beware the steamwyrm's kettle-cry, it bubbles through the dusk—  
The kyusu croons a crooked tune of jade and dewdrop musk.  
With grip of claw and porcelain law, it pours what can't be sipped:  
A single drip, a phantom slip, the sencha's time has dipped.  

Through misthatch glens where kettles croon and crockery turns its eye,  
The steepbeast stirs in ceramist fur, beneath the saucered sky.  
Its tail a spout, its breath a shout of tannin-tangled steam—  
It waits for those who dare oppose the pourer's waking dream.  

He took the strainer, silver-scored, and clicked the lid thrice tight;  
He warmed the cup, he drank it up, he vanished into white.  
The drip drew near, a hiss—so near!—it split the steam with dread—  
With snip-snap pour, he slammed the door, and lopped the dripbeast's head.  

Then back he came, through teatime flame, with trophy drip in tow—  
The kettle still, the kyusu chill, the steamwyrm's echo low.  
"Oh, did you smite the sencha sprite? The drip that dared to fall?"  
He sipped the hush, the steamy plush... and heard the kettle call.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "split‑grade enlarger burn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Split-Grade Burn**

'Twas dimlight in the darkroom's hush,  
Where safelights glowed in crimson blush;  
The slithy negatives did coil—  
Awaiting split-grade's seething toil.  

Beware the Split-Grade Burn, my son!  
Its dodge and flash, its grade-one run!  
Avoid the contrast dragon's flare,  
The grainy claws, the flare-eyed stare!  

He took the loupe and filter pack,  
With timer set and focus back;  
He dodged the shadow, eased the flame—  
The Burnfrog snarled and called his name.  

One-click! The base lit fierce and bright,  
Two-blink! The image snapped to sight,  
He slashed the glare with torch in hand,  
And fixed the print with final stand.  

And as he rinsed and hung to dry,  
He whispered thanks, heaved out a sigh—  
The Burn was bested, contrast tamed,  
The darkroom beast no longer maimed.  

'Twas dimlight in the darkroom's hush,  
The safelight blinked—no final rush;  
The Burn, now caged in emulsion deep,  
At last admitted slumber's sleep.
